slides.title: Introduction to Validation in PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Introduce validation in PolicyCenter and its role in ensuring data integrity and adherence to business rules.
slides.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Validation in PolicyCenter. In this session, we'll explore how validation ensures data integrity and enforces business rules across PolicyCenter. Understanding validation is crucial, as it dictates how data is entered, saved, and processed. We'll delve into different types of validations, from field-level checks to comprehensive job-level evaluations, to ensure your PolicyCenter implementation maintains high data quality standards.

slides.title: Understanding the Data Model
slides.notes: Discuss the importance of the data model and how validation interacts with entities and fields.
slides.narration: Before diving deeper, let's consider the data model in PolicyCenter. It's the backbone of how data is structured, and validation is intricately tied to it. Each entity and field can have specific validation rules that ensure only correct and consistent data enters your system. Understanding this relationship is fundamental for customizing validation to meet your unique business needs.

slides.title: The Role of PCF Configuration
slides.notes: Explain how PCF files are used to configure the UI and validation behavior.
slides.narration: PCF files, or Page Configuration Files, are where the magic of UI configuration happens in PolicyCenter. They don't just dictate layout—they also influence validation behavior. By configuring fields as required or defining input masks, you're setting the stage for how users interact with the system. Mastering PCF configuration allows you to tailor the user experience and maintain data accuracy effortlessly.

slides.title: Validation with Field Validators
slides.originalNotes:
Validation with field validators
A field validator is a pattern tied to one or more fields in the data model. If a field value does not match the prescribed pattern, data cannot be saved and an error message is displayed. Field validators are useful when the validation logic involves simple pattern matching and the pattern holds true every time the field is used. Input-masks can be specified at the data model level or in a user interface ( Ul) widget's property, so that certain information is stored in a certain format. For example, the digits in zip code or postal codes are separated by and SSN numbers or official IDs are also separated by after a pre- determined number of digits. An input mask appears as a field watermark, and disappears when the user enters data in the field. For example, in Date of Birth, the input mask restricts the user input which must match a prescribed pattern.

slides.narration: Field validators are your go-to solution for ensuring data consistency at the field level. These validators check whether input matches a specified pattern, such as zip codes or SSNs, before allowing data to be saved. By using input masks at the data model or UI level, you help guide users in entering data correctly, enhancing both user experience and data integrity.

slides.title: Validation When Data is Saved
slides.originalNotes:
Validation when data is saved
A field marked as required must contain a value. The user cannot proceed to the next page or screen without entering a value in the required field. There is a required property on the field in PCF that can be configured to make a field required. The validatable entities are those marked at the data model level which will trigger validation before data is committed to the database.

slides.narration: When it comes to saving data, required fields play a pivotal role. Configuring a field as required in a PCF ensures that users must provide input before proceeding. Additionally, validatable entities invoke validation processes before data is committed to the database, ensuring that only complete and accurate records are stored. This mechanism is vital for maintaining high-quality data throughout the system.

slides.title: Validation at Various Job Stages
slides.originalNotes:
Validation at some level during a job
Conditions during a job (policy transaction) may return a warning or an error depending on the level within the job. This can be configured to have the desired validation results. Some validation levels are Load and Save, Default, Quick Quotable, Quotable, Bindable and Ready for Issue. For example, if a Personal Auto submission in the base application does not have a vehicle defined, and the user attempts to navigate away from the Vehicles page, the IJI will display a warning message so the user can enter other policy data and return to the Vehicles page later. An error message will be displayed when the Quote button is clicked; a vehicle must be entered in order to receive a valid quote.

slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, validations are not limited to data entry alone—they extend to various stages of a policy job. Depending on the job level, such as Load, Save, or Quote, validations can trigger warnings or errors. For instance, a missing vehicle in a Personal Auto submission might raise a warning during navigation but will prevent quoting without resolution. This layered validation approach ensures that critical data is captured at the right time.

slides.title: Handling Warnings and Errors
slides.originalNotes:
Warnings and errors
After PolicyCenter detects a validation issue, a message is displayed showing errors and warnings. Clearing a validation warning does not remove or correct the issue, you will be able to continue entering data . Fields in the user interface can be validated, however, situations causing the error must be rectified before the user can reattempting the same action. For example, the •Quote" button may have been clicked, and an error issued. In order to "Quote“ successfully, the error must be fixed . However, they can •continue" taking other actions including, but not limited to, the ones required to fix the error.

slides.narration: When PolicyCenter detects validation issues, it presents them as warnings or errors. Warnings inform users of potential issues but allow them to continue, while errors must be resolved before proceeding. This distinction helps users prioritize actions and ensures that critical errors are addressed promptly to maintain data integrity and process continuity.

slides.title: Best Practices for Validation
slides.notes: Highlight key best practices for implementing validation effectively in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Implementing validation effectively requires adherence to best practices. Focus on keeping validation logic as simple and clear as possible, and utilize field validators for consistent patterns. Remember to test thoroughly to ensure validations work as intended and provide meaningful feedback to users. These practices will help maintain data quality and enhance user satisfaction.

slides.title: Common Validation Challenges
slides.notes: Discuss typical challenges developers face with validation and how to overcome them.
slides.narration: Even with robust validation systems, challenges can arise. Common issues include overly complex validation logic, performance impacts, and user confusion. To overcome these, prioritize simplicity, optimize validation checks, and provide clear error messages. By addressing these challenges head-on, you can ensure a smooth and effective validation process.
